name: Tokyo
intro_vibe: The Electric Capital: Where ancient tradition meets neon-lit future.

general_info.description: Tokyo is not just a city; it is a high-efficiency operating system designed to process 37 million people. It is defined by rigid unwritten protocols ('Meiwaku' or avoiding nuisance) and complex logistical flows. To enjoy it, you must shift from being a passive tourist to an active participant in its rhythm.

etiquette_tips: The 'Meiwaku' Rule: The golden rule of Tokyo is 'Meiwaku'—avoiding nuisance to others. This explains why trains are silent and backpacks are worn on the front. It is not just politeness; it is infrastructure.
Silence is Social Glue: Noise creates social friction. Talking on the phone on the train is a major taboo. Conversations should be hushed. Silence is an active behavior to respect shared space.
Tabearuki (No Eating While Walking): Walking while eating is frowned upon ('sloppy'). If you buy street food, stand near the shop to eat it, dispose of trash there, and then move on.

The Trash Reality: There are NO public trash cans (a legacy of 1995 security measures). Carry a Ziploc bag for your trash. Disposal nodes are at Konbini, vending machines (bottles only), and train platforms.
Escalator Logic: Stand on the LEFT, walk on the RIGHT. This is rigidly enforced by peer pressure. (Note: It swaps in Osaka to Stand Right/Walk Left).

Procedural Politeness: Japanese politeness is about correctness and efficiency, not emotional warmth. A lack of smiles doesn't mean they are rude; it means they are focused on doing their job perfectly.
Shoes Off: Look for the entryway step (genkan). If there are slippers, use them. Never wear toilet slippers outside the bathroom.

essential_phrases.note: The ultimate multi-tool word. Use it to call a waiter, apologize, or say thanks. It implies 'I am sorry for the trouble'.
Use this only for personal mistakes/apologies.

neighborhoods.name: Shinjuku
neighborhoods.description: The world's busiest transport hub. Navigate by cardinal direction: East Gate = Neon/Noise (Kabukicho). West Gate = Verticality/Business (Skyscrapers). South Gate = Shopping/Open Air. Do not cross East-West underground unless you know the route.

neighborhoods.name: Shibuya
neighborhoods.description: Defined by verticality and valley topography. The station is a stack; the Ginza line is on the 3rd floor, others are deep underground (B5). Use 'Urban Cores' (elevators) to move up. Home to youth culture.

neighborhoods.name: Yanaka
neighborhoods.description: A rare survivor of WWII bombings. Low-rise buildings, many temples, and a distinct residential vibe. Walk the 'Yanesen' route from Ueno to Nippori for a glimpse of pre-war Tokyo.

neighborhoods.name: Daikanyama & Ebisu
neighborhoods.description: The 'Brooklyn of Tokyo'. Stylish, expensive, and residential. Home to T-Site bookstore and riverside walks. This is where fashionable Tokyoites spend their weekends.

neighborhoods.name: Shimokitazawa
neighborhoods.description: The hipster capital. Narrow pedestrian streets packed with vintage clothing stores and indie cafes. Check out the new 'Bonus Track' greenway connecting to Setagaya-Daita.

neighborhoods.name: Koenji
neighborhoods.description: Raw, lived-in, and famous for its punk rock roots and vintage culture. A great place to experience 'everyday' Tokyo life away from the glitz.

logistics.title: Local Survival Tips
details: Station Shock: Major stations are mini-cities. Exiting the wrong side (e.g., East vs West in Shinjuku) puts you 20 mins away. Check exit numbers carefully.
Last Train Protocol: Trains stop between 23:30-00:30. 'Last Train' often means to the terminal, not *your* station. Missing it means a $50+ taxi or a Manga Cafe stay.
Rush Hour: Avoid trains 7:30am-9:00am. It is physical crush capacity. Silence is mandatory.
Luggage: Don't haul bags. Use 'Takkyubin' (Black Cat) to ship luggage between hotels for ~$20.

logistics.title: IC Card Reality (2025)
logistics.summary: Physical Suica cards are scarce. Go mobile.
details: The Shortage: Due to chip shortages, physical Suica/Pasmo cards are hard to buy. 'Welcome Suica' (tourist version) is available ONLY at airports.
Mobile Suica: The Gold Standard. Add 'Suica' to Apple Wallet. Charge with Mastercard/Amex (Visa often fails). Works even if phone battery dies.
Day Passes: Often a false economy. They limit you to Metro lines and exclude JR (Yamanote), causing slower travel. Pay-as-you-go is better.

logistics.title: Money & Wifi
logistics.summary: Cash is King. Wifi is spotty.
details: Cash Rule: Always carry ¥20,000. Many ramen shops and ticket machines are still cash-only.
7-Eleven ATMs: The most reliable for foreign cards. 24/7.
Connectivity: Public Wifi is unreliable. Pre-arrange an eSIM or Pocket Wifi. Navigation without live data is impossible.

logistics.title: Nightlife Safety
logistics.summary: Tokyo is safe, but Touts are predatory.
details: The Tout Rule: NEVER follow a street promoter in Kabukicho or Roppongi. The script is 'Massages?' or 'Cheap drink?'. You will be spiked and drained of thousands.
Defense: Ignore them completely. Do not say 'maybe later'. Walk with purpose.
Safe Zones: Stick to Golden Gai (regulars only?), listening bars (Jazz Kissa), or craft beer spots.

must_eat.description: The real lunch of Tokyo. A balanced tray with a main (grilled fish, ginger pork, karaage), rice, miso soup, and pickles. Fast, healthy, and served at chains like Ootoya or Yayoiken.
Tokyo's social release valve. Note the 'Otoshi': a mandatory table charge (¥300-500) that comes with a small appetizer. It is not a scam; it is the cover charge. Shout 'Sumimasen!' to order.
Located in basements of department stores (Isetan, Mitsukoshi). A wonderland of high-end bento, sweets, and gifts. Go at 7:30pm for the discount rush. Great for hotel room picnics.
Standing bars for salarymen. Cheap, loud, and social. Often Cash-on-Delivery (COD), making them scam-proof and authentic. Try Shimbashi or Ueno.
Don't look for eggs and toast. The local breakfast is either a traditional set (rice, fish) or a convenience store pastry. Cafes opening before 10am are rare.
Soul food. Order via ticket machine. 'Eat, wipe, leave'—lingering is rude. One bowl per person is mandatory. Do not share.
Life support systems. 7-Eleven for Bento, FamilyMart for Fried Chicken (Famichiki), Lawson for sweets. Also use them for ATMs, toilets, and tickets.
Breaded, deep-fried pork cutlet. Crisp, juicy, and surgically precise. Served with shredded cabbage (often refillable).

items.description: Traditional covered shopping arcades. No big brands, just local butchers, tea shops, and croquette stands. This is where real life happens.
The neon soul of Tokyo. Wander Omoide Yokocho (Piss Alley) for smoky yakitori. Avoid the touts in Kabukicho.
200+ tiny bars in narrow alleys. Safe but tight. Large groups (3+) are often turned away. Cover charges apply.
Tokyo's oldest temple. Go at 6:00 AM for spiritual quiet or after 8:00 PM for atmosphere. Mid-day is a crush.
A serene forest in the middle of the city. Dedicated to Emperor Meiji. A peaceful escape from the Harajuku crowds.
The best FREE view in Tokyo. See Mt. Fuji on a clear day. Less crowded than Shibuya Sky. Located in West Shinjuku.
Immersive digital art where you walk barefoot through water. Extremely popular—book weeks in advance.

affiliate_products.title: Japan Travel Adapter (Type A/B)
affiliate_products.reason: Japan uses Type A (two flat pins). European/UK travelers need an adapter.

affiliate_products.title: eSIM for Data
affiliate_products.reason: Public Wifi is poor. You need constant data for Google Maps/Translate. An eSIM is the easiest solution.

affiliate_products.title: Coin Purse
affiliate_products.reason: Cash is king. You will accumulate a LOT of coins (100 and 500 yen). A dedicated purse is essential.
